summary: This is a transcript of a scheduling conference in the criminal case United States v. Jeffrey Epstein (19 Cr. 490) before Judge Richard M. Berman. The prosecution and defense attorneys discuss and propose a schedule for discovery, motions, and a trial date, with the defense requesting a trial in September 2020 and citing complex legal issues including a non-prosecution agreement (NPA) and double jeopardy.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The accused in the criminal case. His defense attorney argues for more time to prepare due to the volume of discovery and the need to assess Epstein's ability to assist in his defense while incarcerated.

persons.name: Richard M. Berman
persons.context: Presiding judge over the scheduling conference. He facilitates the discussion on case timelines and makes rulings on scheduling and Speedy Trial Act exclusions.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, whose office is prosecuting the case. He is listed as appearing but does not speak in the transcript.

persons.name: Martin G. Weinberg
persons.context: Defense counsel for Jeffrey Epstein. He argues for a later trial date (post-Labor Day 2020), citing the need to review over a million pages of discovery and litigate complex issues related to a non-prosecution agreement and double jeopardy.

persons.name: Michael C. Miller
persons.context: Attorney from Steptoe & Johnson, LLP, also representing Jeffrey Epstein. He is listed as appearing but does not speak in the transcript.

keyFacts: The defense estimates receiving over a million pages of discovery from the government.
The defense plans to file motions challenging the prosecution based on a prior non-prosecution agreement (NPA) and double jeopardy grounds, indicating a core defense strategy.
The FBI is reviewing data from devices seized from Jeffrey Epstein's New York residence, requiring a separate privilege-review protocol.

The prosecution emphasized a "public interest" in bringing the case to trial swiftly, while the defense argued the long delay (alleged conduct 14-17 years prior) made defense preparation more difficult.
Judge Berman excluded time under the Speedy Trial Act until June 8, 2020, citing the complexity of the case and the need for effective counsel preparation.
